remixed_from.title: Sleeve Case for Raspberry Pi B+

title: Raspberry Pi B+ / 2 / 3 Case with cutouts for CAM/GPIO and optional camera mount

description.text:
Hi all,
this is another modified version of Walters's great Raspberry Pi 2/B+ case (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:604915). I changed some dimensions for a better fit since the original model was too tight (it worked, but I was afraid of ripping my Pi apart when removing the case).
Additionally there are cutouts für GPIO and for the camera connector, as well as an optional camera housing on a ball joint giving many possibilities for positioning. The camera mount is fully optional and requires a DIN 912 M3x10 screw (or similar). You have to drill a hole (2,5 mm) for the screw to attach the joint to the case. The small hole in the camera housing is for positioning and drilling a 6 mm hole for nice fit on the ball joint. It is intended to have the camera housing legs bended a bit for good fit. Btw. the camera mount is independent of the case and can be used with everything, you can cut a thread in. The images attached are the results of printing the model on a Reprap Neo in PLA, 0,2 mm layer height and 0,5 mm nozzle. I hope the models turn out usefull for some of you! Update: Camera pin was too big for some so added a smaller one.
Update 2: Added Model with cutouts for DSI, Camera and GPIO (a standard 40 pin IDE connector fits), but please be aware, that it might be only properly printable with support enabled.

The case without camera mount works out of the box. The camera mount requires the following finishing work:
  • one DIN 912 M3x10 screw
  • drill one 2,5 mm hole somewhere on the pi case for the screw
  • drill two 6 mm holes in the camera housing legs for nice fit on the ball joint (if it's too tight try drilling bigger holes)
  • drill one 3,5 mm hole in the ball joint for the screw and a 6 mm cutting for the screw head (be careful not to cut too deep)

comments.author: Quixotic

comments.text:
Thanks for taking your time on my design. As you mention, fits are a critical thing in 3D printing and much more difficult to archive than with conventional manufacturing techniques sice the tolerances are typically way bigger, furthermore precision and calibration vary heavily between printers in a range often bigger than tolerances that distinguish different kinds of fits.
My approach to fits in 3D printing so far is empirical, taking the factory side calibration as it is and adjusting my parts to work with it. Unfortunately this contradicts the idea of sharing parts that are expected to work everywhere. Fortunately scaling of one part of a fitting in most cases helps, but often needs a few approaches.
If it helps I can publish the sources of the parts, which are Autodesk Inventor 2015 files. Just let me know :)

description.text: For this project, I made a wood box with circle cutouts.  This projct will be used for decoration.

1) Use boxmaker.com to create a 4 by 4 by 4 box template
2) Save the box template as a jpg and open in illustrator
3) On 5 of the 6 sides, create different size circles that will be cut out during the printing process
4) Before printing, make sure the cirlces and the box templates have a stroke of 0.001
5) Press print and go to the printer preferences
-the printer setting should be:
-600 DPI
-Vector Speed 17
-Vector Power 100
-Vector Frequency 500
6) Once this prints, pop out each side of the box and glue together

An earring made from the canadian flag!
Best printed in red for Canada Day.

title: Flower Box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: For this project I created a wooden box with flower and spiral designs.  The box is for decoration.

To make this I used boxmaker.com to get a template for my 4 by 4 by 6 box. I then opened the document in Illustrator and changed the stroke of the paths to 0.001. Then I added images of flowers that had been Live Traced to help with the rastering. In Illustrator, I Live Traced the photo and adjusted the settings. Next, I created spirals on the two square sides. I sent the document to the CNC Laser with the following settings:
  • DPI: 600
  • Raster Speed: 100
  • Raster Power: 50
  • Vector Speed:17
  • Vector Power:100
  • Vector Frequency: 500
    Lastly, pop out each piece and glue them together.
    If I were to do this project over I would make the rastering darker.

description.text: This was scanned using an Xbox 360 Connect and Skanect software. I imported the STL into TinkerCAD to crop and add the base.
Prints best with supports.

Every Prankster needs a Dribble Glass!   
Hey folks, I made a classic Dribble Glass. See File: Dribble Glass 001.STL  
But, in playing with that I found that the water hardly comes out of the holes and I had to increase the hole size a lot (with small drills) to get good dribble action.   
So, I decided to take a different tact on this old design and I created a Dribble Glass based on water pressure and so it really dribbles! There are no visible holes at the top of the cup and it is harder to detect where it dribbles from. This design does take three parts and they must be bonded together without clogging the dribble paths. See Files: Dribble Glass 004.STL, Dribble Glass 004-Base.STL and Dribble Glass 004-Top Ring.STL  
Go ahead have a little fun. Of course at the expense of your victims!!! LOL   
Note on bonding. Use drinking glass from kitchen as a mold to form a piece of alum foil over the opening. Remove formed alum foil. It is now shaped like a deep dish. Pour a small amount of Acetone in the alum dish. Place end of main cup in dish, move around and get entire end saturated and softened. Apply to cup base or cup top ring quickly and with pressure (IE: press down against table top).  This is an important step for the bottom cap because you must get full adhesion all around. And make sure to clock the base to the cup body so dribble paths are aligned.   
Enjoy, Reamo

comments.text: Yea, glass with floral design, would make any water path hard to see. That’s a real dribble glass. When I tried this with 3D printing there isn’t anything to distract your eye from the holes; I’m missing the refractions that glass gives.  The hidden path design adds a couple parts but fixes this problem. This design might be best created on a 3D Printer; would be hard to replicate in casting or injection molding. Thanks, Reamo

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Shotgun tracer to mount on a TM M870 Breacher. Fits tight over the barrel and shelltube-screw. Off course, you have to get the tube, electronics, tracer, to work with this. This design is made for the TM tracer models. (not the B&T) Check the 'Shotgun Tracer: Making off' photo album on https://www.facebook.com/blarock86cd to see how to make it. I only ask to leave the design as it is. No modifications.
Off course, you can design your own base for different shotguns, or make another kind of tracer-support.

Check the 'Shotgun Tracer: Making off' photo album on https://www.facebook.com/blarock86cd to see how to make it. You have to know some soldering skills, and be aware of the High-voltage!! on the yellow capacitors. Housing and base were printed with 25% infill and 1mm (3 layers) perimeter. Don't be cheap with these settings. This is the BB-shield :P

author: michael_free

description.text:
I saw this structure in a science paper about structures that were lightweight, and extremely strong. I thought it would be cool to see how these structures fared when 3d printed with different materials, such as ABS and PLA. It would be really interesting trying to print the dual extrusion one with flexible material!
http://youtu.be/gWzZAD5pkUs

The paper I got this structure from is here: http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/full/science.1240889/DC1 You can start to assemble the parts according to the video in the Gallery above after printing!

3D printable corners and laser cut faces allow you to make larger objects than the print volume of your 3D printer. This was generated from a dodecahedron STL file with my corners and faces program for 3mm acrylic or wood. More info: https://trmm.net/Corners If wireframe is more your thing, I've also generated just the edges. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:653464

An adapter for a ballscrew and nut bought at aliexpress (SFU 1204-3), which makes it easy to mount on the existing aluminum bed. I paid 19 USD + shipping for the screw and nut, including custom milling of the ends to 8mm. Easily worth it :)
bought from this vendor: http://www.aliexpress.com/store/920371 The only downside to this mod is slightly decreased maximum print height, as the adapter adds 6mm on top of the bed compared to mounting the ballscrew directly.

The center hole for the axle needs to be drilled out, but no other holes needs to be drilled. The pictures in the gallery should explain the rest. BOM:
4x M3 nuts
4x M3x8 mm screws
2x M4x16 mm bolts
2x M4 nuts with washers

description.text: http://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?t=2350336#post30820665

Along with the STL's is an easily configurable scad file for making adjustments. The default values are what are used in the Standard design download. Below is a list of the easy adjustments
  • Structure Heights
  • Motor Size
  • Motor Mount Tilt
  • Mount Resolution
  • Mount Wall
  • Flight Controller Mounts (Micro MWC, AfroMini, AlienWii)
  • Flight Controller Position

MTM: 117mm
Motor: 6 – 8.5mm
Weight: 6.5 – 8g
License: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial

The following STL's have a resolution of 24 without a Flight Controller Mount.
All of the STL's are also available at http://redbird.club/download/gains/micro Scad File
micro_hex.scad 6mm Motors
micro_hex_m6_standard.stl (Standard Design)
micro_hex_m6_10deg.stl (10º Motor Mount Tilt)
micro_hex_m6_15deg.stl (15º Motor Mount Tilt) 7mm Motors
micro_hex_m7_standard.stl (Standard Design)
micro_hex_m7_10deg.stl (10º Motor Mount Tilt)
micro_hex_m7_15deg.stl (15º Motor Mount Tilt) 8.5mm Motors
micro_hex_m85_standard.stl (Standard Design)
micro_hex_m85_10deg.stl (10º Motor Mount Tilt)
micro_hex_m85_15deg.stl (15º Motor Mount Tilt) This design was generally inspired by the iconic Blackout Mini-H and Spider Hex. I shared it with sp3cialk in a rcgroups thread and other people asked for it so here it is.
The SCAD file attached allows for modifying the following aspects: Resolution, Motor Size, Motor Wall, Motor Tilt, Structure Heights, OSHW Logo Download OpenScad here: http://www.openscad.org/

description.text:
These are some extra parts i made for my 3D printed bike. Thanks to: Functional Bicycle
by thomasgivan, published Apr 24, 2014
thing:309158 https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:309158 Thankyou for an exceptional job on the bike. Love mine. Thought i'd add my additions for others to enjoy. The basket is printed flat and will need to be bent backwards and supper glued. The printed bottom is the inside of basket. The basket brackets are just hooks to glue to the basket. Print 2 of them. The kickstand is also in 2 parts, Use a small piece of 3mm plastic to glue up. May latter put up a diagram of glueing it. Not hard just heat with a match fine flame the end of the raw piece of plastic to make a small ball on the end. Now push thru the long piece hole so it will stop at the blob end of the plastic. Push the other end into the bracket part and clip the excess plastic off leaving maybe less that 1/8th inch extending into the round part of the bracket. Now do the same on that end with a fine flame, yet this time you want it to stick to your part. So heat, blob, and know push it smooth with your finger to make nice and round again. No bumps so it will glue nice to the bike frame. Done well it will have just the right resistance on the kickstand so it holds up when kicked up. :) You may need to run a 1/8th inch drill bit thru the holes for the raw plastic to go in. The name plate is just a small flat piece printed. You may just want to use scissors and cut you a small piece of card board. What ever. Thats it now you have a basket, kickstand and name plate for your personal 3D printed bike. Hope you enjoy, Happy 3D printing, Rick. Just a NOTE: On the basket, you may want to wad up a napkin of some paper to stuff in the basket and then use a rubber band to hold in place while gluing. And also, on the kickstand, just remember to leave room for the pedals to rotate. Do not glue it too close to the pedals on the frame. Just thought i'd add this for for-thought before you make the mistake i nearly made myself on the kickstand. Happy Printing, Rick.

author: shardikk

description.text:
design of my latest 250 quadcopter. the camera side is decoupled from the motor side (to a certain degree), in order to reduce jelloing. this seems to be necessary on this wooden frame since the hobbyking baby beast brushless motors generate a lot of vibrations. here's a build video:
http://youtu.be/2iIHp7ocvd4 here's a video of one of the first flights:
http://youtu.be/Y3LKt2j9npY the cad model was drawn in creo elements express 6, a cad program from ptc that is available for free.

get the following components:
  • 4x motors, baby beast 2206 2150kv (hobbyking)
  • 4x escs, afro 12 amps (hobbyking)
  • naze32, flash with cleanflight (hobbyking)
  • camera, mini cmos fpv camera 520tvl (hobbyking)
  • video transmitter (tbs)
  • camera, mobius
  • propeller 5030 (hobbyking)
  • receiver
  • various m3 bolts
  • "vibration damping balls 100g" (hobbyking)
  • lipo 1500 mah, 3s
    • laser cut paint and glue as follows:
  • cut base plate from 6 mm poplar plywood
  • cut remaining plates from 2 mm birch plywood
  • 3d print the motor mounts (tilts the motors by around 5° towards the center, which is supposed to improve stability)
  • glue the vibration dampener adaptors to the frame

comments.text: Any particular reason you choose those woods? Or were those just what you had on hand?
comments.author: WafflesLaw

comments.text:
I like the 6 mm poplar plywood for its light weight, its rigidity (at this thickness), its low cost and its ease with which it can be laser cut. But I'm sure there are alternatives that are lighter and more rigid. The problem with poplar plywood is its strength. I just crashed the quadcopter a few days ago pretty hard, now I have to make a new frame.
The 2 mm birch plywood (5 layers) is stiff and has great strength but it's a bit heavy. Next time I might use 1.5 mm thickness to save a bit of weight.
Do you have any other suggestions regarding the material choice?
comments.author: WafflesLaw

comments.text: I'm just starting my research into building my a quadcopter from scratch and was just wondering about your choice of materials. I'm going to be asking around about materials I have access to. If I find anything out I'll be sure to pass it along.

author: Fiacre

description.text:
For an iPhone4 version, go here: thingiverse.com/thing:65553
For an iPhone5 version, go here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:59126 It's a case for an 4th Generation iPod Touch. There are many important differences between this case and others on Thingiverse. The most sensitive part of an iPod is the edge of the glass. (The face of the glass is also sensitive, but we can't cover that!) Other cases do not offer much protection for the edge of the glass. Also other cases have a sloppy fit. This case solves both problems. This case is made from two halves that slide onto the iPod and snap together. When it snaps together, there is a strangely satisfying click! The two halves fit together very tightly, and will not accidentally come loose.

Print both halves separately. Because the surface finish is super important for a good looking case, use the highest resolution settings and slow down the speed. Having the filament diameter dialed in is also important. Do not use rafts or supports. This is designed with "mouse ears" and supports included in the STL. After printing, some minor filing/sanding might be required on the dovetail joint. Also, break off the built-in "mouse ears" and file/sand down the spot where they broke off. The amount of filing/sanding should be minimal. It takes me about 2 minutes to do this step. I printed this on a Replicator 2 in PLA with ReplicatorG/Skeinforge. My settings were:
Layer Height: 0.1
Infill: 100%
Shells: 0
Feedrate: 40
Travel Feedrate: 75 Remember to get your temperature and filament diameter set appropriately for your filament. On my Replicator 2 it took about 3-3.5 hours for each half. About 6.5 to 7 hours total. Taking the case off of the iPod can be tricky the first time you do it. What you do is pry up two of the dovetails on the same side with shim-like things. They don't need to be raised very much, just so they clear the case back. With the shims in place, just pull the halves apart. Make sure that your pry-bar/shim will not scratch the iPhone. I have used things like bamboo skewers, saxophone reeds, and nylon zip-ties for this task. I have included the Solidworks file for this design, so people can modify it. There are two elements in the design called "Top Cutoff" and "Bottom Cutoff". Use the suppress/unsuppress functions to basically select which half of the case is "active", then save the STL file for that half.

And by tuned, I am mostly referring to how much plastic the extruder is extruding as well as the retraction/deprime.  You can look at the broad flat sides of the printed case as an indicator.  The smoother the sides, the better tuned the printer is.

comments.text: It wouldn't print correctly if it were lying flat.  If the LCD side were facing up then the gentle curve on the bottom/back would have an inconsistent surface finish, and there are terrible overhangs.  But if the LCD were facing down then the entire back would need supports and that would mess up the fit around the iPod.  With it oriented the way I did, the surface finish is mostly consistent and there are no terrible overhangs-- it just needs a little cleaning up after printing.

title: Parametric arduino box for cnc router

description.text: Derived from a box for laser cutter. I wanted a parameteric version for various material sizes. Could be used for any general purpose box

There are some variables at the top of the file that control the thickness of material you want to use. and the INTERNAL dimentions you desire. In theory the model should then adjust appropriately to set all the tab holes/notches etc to the appropriate sizes for your material. It should also ensure the spacing of the parts is enough for my cnc router to use a 3mm cutter. the spacing is proportional to the material thickness. Obviously the parent of this object was done on a laser cutter where spacing was less of an issue. In this example I also have the mounting holes / pintout slots and usb/power cut outs for putting an aduino uno inside. However it should be easy to comment out those and add other details for whatever other purpose you want this kind of box for. I've tried it set at 3mm which is the shown box image. That version didn't have quite enough support for the corner holes, so in this version of the scad file I've added a little more boarder to allow the holes to be better supported.
At 3mm I also needed to use a craft knife to clean up the internal corners where the diameter of the bit was significant to the detail of the box. I will try it at 4mm and update.

author: danielwould

description.text: This is from the movie Man of Steel; I wanted to make it.

Well after about 10 flights with my Gemini racer the stock board camera died. I had a DX-201 on the shelf and since it is such an awesome camera I thought I would design a mount for it to fit in the Gemini. It was quite a challenge but I got it to fit, and all canopies and stock electronics remain unaffected by this new mount. And you can still hang the Mobius from it too, in exactly the same way the stock mount does it. It is a drop in replacement for the Gemini stock mount. Only thing you'll need besides this thing is a DX-201, it's cable and 2x 2mm x 6mm long screws. Otherwise uses the stock hardware to mount to the frame.   
Update 2-17-15: I revised the "whole" version. It was supposed to have chamfers where the sides of the DX-201 lens housing meets the printed part.

The whole version is for those who don't mind using supports, or have a hips capable printer. If you hate supports, you can try the split version, which will require gluing the parts together post assembly. Either approach works well. Use 100% infill and two shells. You will have to clean up the small holes with a 2mm drill post print. This mount works great, you won't have to change the location of any of the stock electronics. The only change is the lens will poke out the front of the canopy about 4mm. Looks great though! IMPORTANT As with all of my things, these models are scaled up 1.019 in the x and y axis to allow for ABS shrinkage on my printer. You may need to invert this scale or change it depending on your printer and material choices.

This is a canvas mount that can be clamped to any canvas to hold a stepper motor and idler bearings for the gocupi drawing bot. The idler posts will hold 8mm VXB 608 ZZ Skateboard Bearings. Drawing Bot: http://www.gocupi.com Canvas Mounts: http://justinwilcott.com/gocupi-large-canvas-and-paint-gondola/ Note: the first photo does not show the idler posts, they were added later.

1/2" hex shaft is very common in FRC robot drive trains and transmissions.  Team 2363 uses our Replicator to make parts for our West Coast Style drive train.  If you print parts with .500" hexes, the printed parts do not fit onto 1/2" hex shafting.  I created this plate to allow the proper sizing of the hex holes in a solid model.

Print the plate with the fill ratio you want to use in your finished parts.
Label the holes as shown in the photo.  Smallest hole is .500", and the holes go to .535" in increments of .005". 
Test fit your hex shaft in the holes starting with the largest size hole and working down.
Select the nominal hole size to give the fit you want between the shaft and the part, and use that size in your part.
Be aware that the top and bottom layers may be smaller than the interior layers of the part.  Filing or trimming the top and bottom layers back with a file or Xacto knife may give a slightly different fit of the shft to the hole.
If you modify your print speeds, accelerations, layer thicknesses, or fill ratios, any of these may affect the fit of the hex holes to the shaft.  Reprint another plate with the new parameters to use for test fitting.
You can also use the outside dimensions of the plate to check how well your machine is holding tolerances.  The plate nominal dimensions are 3.4375 x 1.75 x .250.  The plate shown in the picture measured 3.423 x 1.752 x .235/.242

The bearings have build in supports that need to be clipped off. The paint pod needs to be glued together. The pod takes a medium paint marker replacement nib.  
I've been experimenting with many paint pod designs, this is the latest one. Could still be improved, any suggestions are welcome in the comments section.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/iYenB4y9GbB

This model is just like the last version of the Mk.III, but has been split up into separate files for most of the parts. When I printed the previous model, I used a raft as well as supports. The Hull Top defiantly needs support; however, the wheels do not as it is hard to remove from the tread. I also had a hard time removing support material from the holes for the axles on the Hull Bottom, but the part "should" not require it. The Axles and Gun will benefit from a raft. All the parts fit really tightly, and the moving parts will need to be filed and or sanded to work freely.
The overall design is simple and geometric with no raised detail to allow for easier filling and sanding of the flat surfaces. The Gatling gun and optics are kit parts, as this vehicle is designed to be detailed with model kit parts. Think of the A.M.V.P. as a platform for whatever you want to put on it. I have found that anime and armor kits offer a plethora of weapons and detail pieces.
If you would like the model in all one file it is available in the previous file-A.M.V.P Mk.III A2 (Chinchilla). Hope you enjoy this little model as much as I have.
Hull Top needs supports, I used a raft on the model I printed.

description.text:
THIS TWO PART, SNAP TOGETHER, ABS SHELL IS THE EXTRAPOLATION OF THE SMALLER VERSIONS PREVIOUSLY PRESENTED.
BECAUSE IT IS TOO BIG TO BUILD IN EITHER OF THE TWO DIMENSION, 3d PRINTERS, THE NEXT STEP WAS TO "CUT THE PIE" IN FOUR (4) WEDGE SHAPED SEGMENTS AND DO FOUR PRINTINGS. ACTUALLY EIGHT (8) WITH FOUR INNER SHELL SEGMENTS AND FOUR MORE OUTER SHELL PIECES.

THIS SET OF DRAWINGS MAKE NO FOR "AIR IN," THEREFORE, A SUITABLE SIZED SPIGOT MUST BE ADDED FOR AN AIR DUCT FROM A BLOWER. A SECOND PRINTING OF THE QUARTERED PIPE SEGMENTS PROVED THAT THE ANNULAR RING NEEDED TO BE CUT INTO SIX (6) SMALLER WEDGES TO BETTER FIT INTO THE RAPID PROTOTYPING PRINTER "BUILD BOX. THIS MIGHT PERMIT TWO SMALLER PARTS TO BE PRINTED SIMULTANEOUSLY IN ONE "RUN." ALSO, IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE WALL THICKNESS NEEDED TO BE AT LEAST .125" FOR STRENGTH. THE KEY TO ASSEMBLING THE 4, 6 OR 8 SHELL PIECES IS AVAILABLE. [email protected]

I liked the concept of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:672318 but the inner heart wouldn't separate from the outer when I printed it. To learn how to design a thing, I created this.

Keuffel & Esser co. Slide Rules produced prior to 1945 suffer from a plastic-like material (bakelite?) that rots over time.  The glass cursors mount on two small rectangular blocks (one on each side of the rule).  The goal of this entry is to provide suitable replacements so one can repair their rule and make it useful again.  (Why do this?  These instruments helped engineers put us on the moon!)

Parts were designed in FreeCAD. Source file included. Printed two with the slot feature facing upward. The slots are intended for a spring to keep things tight and aglined, but I have almost a perfect fit with my rule. If it is loose on yours then use a spongy material or a piece of zip tie to make a spring in the slots to keep things nice and tight. Printed on a Printrbot Simple 1401 maker's edition with 0.4mm nozzle, 0.2 mm layer height, @ 195 deg C on slow speed settings. The image of a damaged cursor assembly was taken from: http://www5b.biglobe.ne.jp/~tomozawa/en/sr-annex/ke-cursor/kercse.htm. (Mine was basically dust after I took it apart.)

comments.text: There was a penned up potential within me that you released. :-)  Never in my life have I owned a slide rule, but I have always respected them and thought they would be good to understand fully both for personal and educational purposes. I just-now went out and bought one on E-bay so (used of course)  These things should be good for tactile learners. :-)  Hopefully I wont need your fixing part but I'm ready if I do. :-)  Retro-geeky stuff is so cool.

description.text: Here's an extension to the Lulzbot Taz electronics enclosure to fit a Raspberry Pi for wireless printing and monitoring of your projects. The extension features room for the existing fan and a built-in holder system to keep the Pi in place. Update: Please use v3 of this model. I've updated the Pi holder to address a problem with the clips breaking. The USB and network ports for the Pi are exposed on the top of the cover and there's groove to allow the Pi camera ribbon cable to pass through. The RAMBo board can supply 5v power to the Pi from the inside of the enclosure, so the system turns on with the TAZ. Works great with Octoprint or Astrobox for Raspberry Pi. This model was designed using Google SketchUp and the measurements taken from the Lulzbot design diagrams for the Taz electronics enclosure. The SketchUp file is included so please feel free to modify to suit your needs. Enjoy!

Update: Please use v3 of this model. I've updated the Pi holder to address a problem with the clips breaking. Print with supports for the box overhangs on the top and bottom. See the included pictures for support locations. Make sure you already have your Raspberry Pi loaded with Octoprint or similar software and that the SD card is in place. Fit the raspberry pi into the enclosure. For v2, take care not to break the clips when you insert the Pi. For v3 (recommended), slide the Pi into the 2 clips at the front, then use an M3x5mm screw to secure the board through the mounting hole (see picture of the black print above). [Power the Pi]
I took an existing micro USB cable to power the Pi and cut the USB-A end off. Then I terminated the V+ and Ground wires using standard female crimp pins for .1" housings and a 2 wire crimp connector housing to make a nice connector to the RAMBo. See the included pictures to find the external power pins on the RAMBo board to connect to. It's labeled on the bottom right of the board and will supply 5v to the Pi when TAZ is turned on. Turn the TAZ off and unscrew the metal electronics enclosure top. Disconnect the fan and unscrew from the original enclosure. Transfer fan to the new extended enclosure with the same hardware plus 4 3mm nuts. Connect the Raspberry Pi USB power to the 5v pins on the RAMBo board and reconnect the fan power. Install the new extended enclosure. If the Raspberry Pi camera module is installed, take care to keep the ribbon cable in the groove at the top before tightening the 4 screws. There should be enough clearance for a USB Wifi module to be installed for wireless communication with the Pi. I used the other USB port and a short cable to connect the Pi to the TAZ. It should be possible to wire the GPIO serial pins from the Pi directly to the serial breakout on the RAMBo board to eliminate the external connection. If you choose to do that, take care to use a logic level converter board in between so that the 3v Pi can communicate with the 5v RAMBo. The RAMBo board exposes multiple serial connections. Serial 0 is shared with the USB. The firmware may need to be modified to communicate over the other serial channels.

description.text: This coin was made to use as an "Inspiration Token" in my Tabletop RPG games. It is awarded to players for role-playing their characters in an impressive manner. They then use it to gain an advantage with two D20's in a situation later in the game. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/2hP0eWVbF1J

Use some superglue to glue the two halves together. There are two holes that you may use for aligning the pieces together. Just extrude some filament from your hot end, cut, and fit into the holes.  
For painting, paint the whole coin silver first. I painted two layers with "Golden Artist Colors - Iridescent Silver (Fine)". I then painted the gold layer a few times with "Golden Artist Colors - Iridescent Bright Gold (Fine)". I came in with some browns on the gold using a fine brush and "MSP Muddy Brown 09028". For the silver, the dark undertones on the grooves of the D20 die and side grooves was with "MSP Shadowed Steel 09052"

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. This is  a work in progress for my phone stand/wireless charging for a variant of phones.

A model rocket kit for Estes BT-55 body tubes. Choose from 4 nose cones and 3 fin sets. Or take the solidworks files and make your own! Based loosely on the Estes Amazon. Wall thickness is 1.6mm, so best printed with a 0.4mm nozzle. base_swept_12.stl is an experimental 1.2mm wall thickness version. This rocket flew beautifully with Estes D12-5, but it should work with other 24x70mm motors like Estes C11. See the Open Rocket simulation file. You can also print 2x 18_mm_motor_adapter and use 18mm motors like Estes C6-3. There's a shock cord mount near the bottom of base_*.stl. If you mount your shock cord here, make sure it's made of kevlar or some other very heat resistant material. Here's a video of the rocket blasting into the sky in slow motion: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r5LMzHydy4g

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes: Designed for ABS. You may need to scale up slightly for PLA. I'm not sure.

• Choose your fins! (one of base_*.stl)
  • Choose your nose cone! (one of nosecone_*.stl)
  • Print 24mm_motor_cap.stl
  • (Optional for 18mm motors) Print 2x 18_mm_motor_adapter.stl
  • Glue base to body tube
  • Sand nosecone to fit loosely in body tube
  • Add a recovery system.
    I use a parachute. There's a loop for mounting a shock cord on base_*.stl.
    There are plenty of excellent guides on the net for building model rocket recovery systems.
  • Install a motor
    24mm? D12-5, C11-5.

description.text:
A platform to get bottles and cans up off the bottom of your shower niche so they can dry to help prevent rust and/or mold.
Update:  Added v2.  New configuration setting for the number of weep holes (fewer holes should speed up printing a bit), has the weep holes go through the side now, and also fixes a few centering problems with various things (e.g., top slats and middle support).   Renamed old SCAD file, so rename it as appropriate when you download it.  This new one seems to work in OK Customizer, but you can probably come up with some unusable configurations if you try.

Edit:  The v2 STL is 190mmx80mmx6mm with 8 weep holes.
Included STL is 200mmx80mmx6mm.  I resized it in my slicing software until it and the skirt would fit my print bed, so the one displayed in the picture is 190mm x 80mm x 6mm.  
It was printed in white ABS with a 0.6mm nozzle, 1.2mm top/bottom and walls (shells).  Infill was set to 50%, but I'm not sure there was any open areas for it to kick in.  
I tried to make sure the SCAD file would be configurable for most uses.

title: SMD Component Reel / Film Reel Holder/Hub (parametric)

description.text:
Hub for SMD Component / Super 8 Film reels.
Reels are varying widths so holder needs customising.
Holder is in two parts which lock the reel in place.
They fit over a bolt (eg a shoulder bolt), with a spring to lock the cap castellations into the rod. Design is optimised for building with minimum support. If you need one of these you might also need http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:482051

printed at 0.35mm on UP printer.
Designed using OpenSCAD version 2015.01.23 (git 5a0c4b0)
(customizer may not work until it uses a more recent version of openscad)
Using a shoulder bolt for the axle is ideal.
Probably should drill out the axle holes to clean them up, rather than make them too oversize.

title: Bearing cap for the simple filament spool stand

description.text: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:281848 is my favorite spool stand. I used horizontal spool stand (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:508896) before and while it's good the horizontal spool stands have the problem when the spool winding is not smooth and that ends up in tangling. But with the vertical spool stands, the gravity works in their favor and not prone to tangling at all. One issue I had with the current spool is that the bearings would fall off easily. So, I created a simple cap for them and I made the cap like a cone to make it easy to remove it. The radius of the bearings is 4mm. The scad has a tolerance that can be set. I printed with 0 tolerance it fit well.

description.text:
This is the latest version of the phone holder for my Land Rover Defender.
I replaced the ashtray in the centre of the dash with this holder that I designed for an iPhone 4 in a HEX wallet.
The holder has a slot in the base for a USB / iPhone connector which plugs into a rear USB slot in the stereo.
This set up gives you access to all of your iPhone music, apps (sat-nav etc.), hands free calls on the move (using the wired microphone which came with the stereo) and it also charges the phone, all without removing it from the wallet!

Print using high resolution settings and 50% fill. I painted mine matt grey to match the buttons on the centre console.
Feed a USB connector through the slot in the base and glue the iPhone connector in position, ensuring it is the correct way round.
Remove the plastic ashtray from the centre of the dash and push the USB connector down into the wiring compartment behind the stereo. Glue the phone holder in position.
Connect up you stereo as per the instructions and away you go!

comments.text: I've never seen a true vertical phone holder before, it looks as if it belongs there. Great thinking using the ashtray in the Defender.

description.text:
This is designed to hold a colorbeam LED board:
https://www.tindie.com/products/ColorBeam/colorbeam/
It centers the LED perfectly. This a neat way to illuminate your projects.
I used a "Noctural Mystra" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:398413) in the photo. The Colorbeam has a kind of soothing movement between colors, not a blinking or flashing.

The PCB mounts using 3 holes in the board, there are 2 pegs that fit in two holes at one end, and a hole in the base by the connector. I have drilled and tapped for a #2-56, (or 2mm screw would work, nothing large tho) You could also make a peg or just use hot glue.  
I used 0.2 mm layer height and 50% fill. I used 3 perimeters although 2 would probably work fine if you aren't drilling and tapping holes.
Inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:566874

title: 3-Way Universal Phone Dock: For the Car, Tripod, & Bicycle

description.text:
I often use the gps app on my phone but there is no convenient place to put it in my car. This 3 way phone mount allows me to hang it from the rear view mirror.  
This phone dock can hold any normal sized smart phone.  
Attaches to car rear view mirror using the hook.  
Attaches to any tripod that uses a 1/4-20 thread mount.  
Attaches to bicycle with zip ties or a hose clamp.

Print everything at 30% infill minimum. You don't want your phone coming loose because you decided to save a little plastic! I added the gray weather stripping to the mount to keep the phone from slipping out. Hardware:
(1) 1/4-20 x 3.5" long hex bolt, (Fully threaded for maximum adjust-ability)
(1) 1/4-20 x .75" long hex bolt (For the hook option)
(1) 1/4-20 butterfly nut
(2) 1/4-20 hex nut (One for the hook option and one for the tripod mount in the base)

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/9SlACLhCCrk

I HAVE MOVED ALL MY DESIGNS TO MY OWN SITE http://www.tmophoto.com/product-category/3d-product-download/
.
.
.
.
.
.
.been trying to track down an annoying rattle ever since switching to the x/y lowrider for months. realized it was the platform rattling agianst the y stage. you will lose the ability to easily take off whatever platform you have if you do this.

get some automotive cork gasket material  
cut it out to the shape of the y stage  
bolt the platform down to the y stage.  
reassemble the platform.  
it helped with a bit of noise reduction on my cupcake.  + I am not worried about the platform coming off when printing really fast

comments.text: Try sorbothane.  It is an excellent vibration absorber.
comments.author: davelandia

comments.text: I like this idea.  It even adds a small amount of  shock absorbance when the plastruder hits the platform at the beginning of a print .  A small amount of gasket sanding could even level the platform for better raftless printing.
comments.author: ElectronicKit

comments.text: springiness and leveling is taken care of with the spring loaded platform, that is a super simple and cheap upgrade, but might be a source of some rattley noise if the springs are not tightened down enough. i got the carrier board here on thingiverse

comments.text: Cupcakes are loud -- but they also sound just so great! (the BotSounds stuff here http://wiki.makerbot.com/makerbot-musichttp://wiki.makerbot.com/maker... is really fun) Also, put some silicone feet on the bot as well to really keep the sound low!

comments.text: the first thing i ever did with mine as soon as it was all wired up was play the imperial death march but i would much prefer to have a completely silent printer.  switching to the polulu stepper drivers was the biggest reduction that i have found so far, then all the ball bearing stuff.  I have also put foam in the power supply area (aka soundbox) I used a big roll of pickup truck topper seal (2"x1/4" with sticky back) and stick on silicone feet and the cork under the motors.  still have some rattles, i think i need to print a new y stage cart, the bearings/washers on that seems to rattle a bit.

title: Hair trap drains for stall shower in 1960's home

description.text:
these are replacement drain covers for a slotted one that lets all the
hair through.
3.25" bolt circle x 3 bolts. Flange is 0.15" thick. OD of flange in 3.62"
One has round drain holes and reinforced bottom. See my other
thing named "Funky" which has a custom designed pattern with a flat
bottom and raised top.

measured the existing one, and then added my own drain hole pattern and thickened midsection for strength. Used visio to draw face pattern (uploaded) and then exported from visio to 123D via SVG format
(attached). Extruded faces then faceted corners after subtracting a
large concave face I created. exported as STL in to MB desktop. For
the FUNKY one, I created a helical pattern overlaid on concentric
circles to create the voids.

description.text: The idea is as yet untested. In theory a 6mm 32 guage insulin needle as used with an insulin pen can be cut out with a trefine and used as an insert with this two part design to provide a 1 gph flow rate for a nursery drip line. The inner nozzle should be thread compatible with the needles if you just want to stick the needle end into a water source. As a diabetic I have a ton of these needles. But watch out for blood born vegetable and pathogens, eh, you can sterilize or use fresh needles! Use line pressure to exactly control flow rate. This thing was made with Tinkercad. author: TenKTech

description.text: This is an amalgamation of a Boots Industries v2.5 frame and BerryBot parts. You can use the printed versions or mill the OpenBuild Parts Store carriage plates and end effectors yourself but www.shopspt.com is creating a kit of the parts currently used on my printer and the relatively small cost difference of $130 is well worth saving hours of fabrication time. Photos of my printer are with the machined aluminum SPT carriages. Kit available here: http://www.shopspt.com/ProductDetails.asp?ProductCode=SPT-Boots-Mod Here is a video of my printer running at 100mm/sec as the first print post SmoothieBoard update: https://youtu.be/d7kqzK0D_Y0

UPDATE 2015-06-04: Uploaded aluminum end effector designed for Chimera and chimera mounting plate. NOTE: the plastic end effector did not meet my rigidity requirements. Plastic parts should only be used for mockup while sourcing aluminum parts.
UPDATE 2015-04-11: New BOM coming as soon as the kit is finalized from SPT.
UPDATE: Uploaded preliminary BOM 2015-03-10 These parts are a placeholder in case someone wants to get started. I'll fill in a full BOM and instructions as I complete this thing and have time to organize the data. Important notes for now:
  • The belt is using a 16 tooth pulley and the upper tower is offset to handle this.
  • Many of these components are no longer necessary if you go with the SPT kit.
  • The EZStruder spacer is not necessary if you use my flying extruder mount.
  • The Boots Industries optical endstops are not compatible with SmoothieBoard enstop input pins. As a result, you must use available normal pins for endstops.
The clock 5 was created with the program Cinema 4D and finished with a UP 3D printer.

description.text: Protective case for Ublox 6m (with backplane) from readytoflyquads. Case has a cut out for better antenna reception and a hole for mounting a piece of glue stick to diffuse led.

Screw holes in bottom allow m3 sized bolt to pass through. Printed with a .2 layer height and tapped holes in top of case for m3 bolt. Cut a piece of glue stick and place in round hole in top case portion to diffuse led from board.

This is a modified version of one of Emmett's Heart Gears (2-3).  I used Blender to split off about 5mm from the top surface of each of the 8 gears.  
It's printing out now at about 50% size, and I already see some issues with the corners of some of the pieces.  I didn't plan properly on support.  When I get some time, I'll try to modify it again to include some built-in (hidden) support.
I'm printing this using Makerware Desktop in White/Pink ABS at 0.2mm layer height, 30% infill and purge wall enabled.

description.text: This thing allows the attachment of filters or other items in front of the objective of a Canon SX50-HS camera. This super-zoom camera has an unusual objective size and regular adapters do not fit. The openscad file can be modified to fit other camera sizes. The adapter has two tiny side tabs that attach to the sides of the objective with a 90 degree rotation. This thing worked very well to attach in front of the camera a small sheet of black polymer solar filter (http://www.thousandoaksoptical.com/solar.html) and take some nice pictures of the sun (you can even see a dark solar spot on the top-right side of the sun image in the picture above). Extension: added adapters to connect standard glass filters and a ring of NeoPixel lights to the front of the Canon SX50-HS objective.
This object printed very well in my printrbot printer with 0.2mm layers, but I had to print three versions with different diameters to get a perfect fit.

title: USB cap for a mini SanDisk drive

description.text: This is a simple cap to replace the lost cap of my mini SanDisk USB drive. It has an internal wall that goes inside the device and tries to hold it in place with two spheric tabs that latch to two holes in the drive. I also added my initials on the side for extra fun (the initials can be changed in the openscad file of course).

I printed the cap with a printrbot at 0.1 mm layer thickness and 100% fill. The internal tabs were not very well resolved but the cap still attaches very well to the USB stick, possibly better than the original cap.

title: Ethernet Port Protector Plug - Reserve / Protect an Ethernet Port
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
IT professionals will appreciate this print. The Ethernet Port Protector Plug (EPPP) lets you reserve/label/protect a port as well as find it easily amongst the 'spaghetti' of other network cables.   
Protect or reserve an Ethernet (RJ45) socket with this plug. Printed on a Replicator 2 it snaps securely into position like any Ethernet plug. When printed in a bright colour it stands out from the 'spaghetti'  so is easy to find, has sufficient length to make it easy to insert/remove but is short enough that it won't stop a server cabinet door from closing.   
The EPPP also has holes that allow a tag to be attached with cable ties or a rubber band so information / notes can be made for quick and easy reference.  
If you like this take time to check out my other designs!

On a Replicator 2 (PLA) print at standard resolution (0.20mm) with 4 shells and 50% infill with Raft on. The EPPP prints upright so the build plate contact patch is small. For this reason, if adhesion issues are a problem, printing 2-up can help, as this helps each layer cool before the next layer is added, as can reducing the print speed to 60 mm/s and giving the build plate a quick with Isopropyl alcohol.   
Usually this shouldn't be necessary if the build plate is well levelled and the machine is working well.

comments.text: Printed it three times with different settings on my Printrbot Simple Metal without success. I'm not able to print it in a way so that it don't break into two pieces when I try to remove it out of an ethernet port ...
comments.author: cleeb1983

comments.text: Sorry to hear your attempts to print this haven't been successful. The fact is not all machines print the same and some slicing apps have problems with the detail in the inner surfaces. Filament also can be the cause of this as well... Lots of people have successfully printed these as I'm sure you've seen and I've lost count of the number I've printed for people on my MakerBots. I assume you followed the instructions provided in which case it has to be due to one or more of the above. I wish I could help further but I know they work for most people and their machines /apps
comments.author: cleeb1983

comments.text:
Hi! This weekend I printed a few of your models (Fish Fossil, Easter Egg and Ethernet cable runners). Really great job, thank you for your designs! And finally, I also was successful with this Ethernet Protector Plug. The solution in my case was, that I had to lay the clip down to the side. The advantage of printing the object in this way is, that there are no tensions between layers when you push the arm to get the Protector out of the ethernet port ...
Thank you again for your creativity and your designs!
